_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Dixie Chemical Company's 50-acre chemical manufacturing facility is located in the Bayport Industrial Complex, 25 miles southeast of Houston, Texas, and operates 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.  Dixie is a global supplier of specialty chemicals in three key market segments:



          Thermoset Materials

          Fuel and Lube Additives

          Alkaline Paper Sizing



Dixie's core chemistry expertise is in functionalizing synthetic and renewable materials through epoxidation, hydrogenation, acrylation, and reactions with maleic anhydride, butadiene, propyleneimine (aziridine), and epichlorohydrin.  Dixie is the only global manufacturer offering a complete line of derivatives based on Diels-Alder and Ene reactions.



Contract chemical processing is also a vital part of Dixie Chemical's operations.  Dixie performs sophisticated custom processing under contracts with other chemical manufacturing companies.  Key features of the facility include:



          Small to large scale equipment versatility

          Multi-step synthesis capability

          Multi-purpose batch manufacturing

          High efficiency Biazzi hydrogenation

          Thin film evaporation

          Multi-tray distillation

          Crystallization and solids handling capability

          cGMP Protocol capabilities



Dixie utilizes seven chemicals in quantities that require inclusion in this Risk Management Plan: 



Toxic Chemicals: epichlorohydrin, propyleneimine, formaldehyde (37%), and hydrochloric acid (37%)

Flammable chemicals: isoprene, 1,3 butadiene, and Dimethylamine (60% aqueous)



Of these chemicals, only propyleneimine is manufactured at Dixie's Bayport Facility.  It is sold as a product and is also used as a raw material in another process.  All other RMP chemicals are used as raw materials.



Each chemical that is subject to RMP regulations is stored in a dedicated storage tank that is located within a containment area sufficient to contain the volume of the

largest tank within the respective area.  This ensures that spills will not leave the process areas or Dixie's plant site.  Most of Dixie's manufacturing efforts are scheduled in campaigns as opposed to continuous processes.  The inventories of the raw material chemicals are kept at a minimum between campaigns, thus reducing the risk associated with these chemicals.



A typical manufacturing operation involves storage of the raw materials in tanks, tanker trailers, or drums; reaction of the raw materials; purification; and packaging of selected product.  Inventories of raw materials, intermediates, and final products are kept at minimum levels to reduce risk.



Worst and alternative scenarios for were calculated for all RMP chemicals used at the Dixie facility.



In worst case scenario: RMP chemicals that are stored in tanker trailers were assumed to release the entire load. RMP Chemicals that are stored in tanks were assumed to release 90% of the entire tank volume to secondary containment. Dixie's policy is to maintain all tank levels below 90% at all times. Alternative case scenarios were calculated based on smaller releases caused by hose failures, loss of an entire reactor charge, etc.  All scenarios were calculated using RMP*Comp.



Dixie Chemical Company is committed to continuous improvement of Environmental, Health, Safety, Security and Quality performance as well as compliance with applicable legal and industry requirements.  Dixie utilizes an integrated management system, ISRS 8th edition (International Sustainability Rating System) by DNV GL. Dixie holds a Level 7 certification from DNV GL. ISRS 8th edition is a world-leading system used to assess, improve and demonstrate the health of an organization's business processes. The system takes a Plan, DO, Check, Act approach to management systems. ISRS describes best practices in safety and sustainability management. In addition, ISRS includes the requirements for major international standards certificat

ion to help guide organizations in building integrated systems to meet certification requirements:



ISO 45001:2018 Occupational Health & Safety Management

ISO 14001:2015 Environmental Management

ISO 9001:2015 Quality Management

ISO 55000:2014 Asset Management

ISO 50001:2019 Energy Management  

OSHA 1910.119 Process Safety Management

Seveso III Directive - 2012/18/UE Process Safety Management



Dixie is committed to continual improvement by investing in annual recertification audits by DNV-GL. These audits consist of 2-5 days of onsite auditing by a 3rd auditor across Dixie's systems. ISRS is are structured with 15 processes embedded in a continuous improvement loop:



1. Leadership

2. Planning and administration

3. Risk evaluation

4. Human resources

5. Compliance assurance

6. Project management

7. Training and competence

8. Communication and promotion

9. Risk control

10. Asset management

11. Contractor management and purchasing

12. Emergency preparedness

13. Learning from events

14. Risk monitoring

15. Results and review.



The annual recertification audit consist of auditing all 15 ISRS process and generating a numeric rating for each process allowing Dixie to identify areas for improvement. In addition to external audits, Dixie also performs multiple interal audits throughout each year. The audits are determined based on a scheduled frequency and could include environmental management, PSM & RMP programs, tasks involving highly hazardous chemicals, maintenance systems, mechanical integrity, safety systems, etc. All audit results are reported through our management systems review meetings.



All plant operating personnel are required to have classroom instruction as well as equipment specific training prior to being able to work independently in any of the manufacturing areas.  A Process Hazards Analysis is completed and operating manuals and procedures, all of which meet Process Safety Management regulations, are in place before starting

to make any of our products.  A team consisting of production, engineering, EHSS, and research personnel is assigned to monitor the startups of all new production campaigns.  A Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) program ensures the safe startup of any unit or device.  A PSSR is completed for all new installations and processes, as well as all applicable modified processes.  Dixie maintains a rigorous Management of Change (MOC) program to ensure that all changes are properly documented and implemented.  All employees receive training on the MOC and PSSR programs and procedures.



Prompt and detailed investigations are performed to determine the root cause and to prevent recurrence of every safety, environmental, process, and other incident.  All records are maintained in a customized software package called Dakota Proactivity Suite.  Types of data managed in Dakota include spills, releases, injuries, near misses, MOCs, and internal & external audits.



Dixie Chemical has a fully trained and functional Emergency Response Team (ERT) consisting primarily of volunteers from operations and maintenance.  Members of the ERT work on rotating shifts so that immediate help is available should an accident, spill, or other emergency occur.  All ERT personnel receive training as specified by OSHA in 29 CFR 1910.120, 1910.156, and the National Fire Protection Association standards.  All ERT personnel receive extensive training and participate in drills designed to certify their current level of readiness.  Drills are evaluated to verify proficiency and to identify areas of improvement. On average, each member receives approximately 100 hours of ERT training annually.



A plant alarm is in place to alert all plant personnel to any emergencies and Dixie subscribes to an internet-based incident reporting system called e-Notify.  The alarm system and e-Notify are tested weekly.  A Community Awareness/Emergency Response (CAER) smartphone app permits citizens to be informed of drills,

emergencies, and other areas of interest.  Dixie's plant radio network is also used to coordinate the actions during any ERT event or incident.



Dixie Chemical is a member of the Channel Industry Mutual Aid organization (CIMA) which provides mutual emergency response from over 50 companies in the event aid is needed.  Dixie's ERT participates in area emergency drills with CIMA and the local LEPC.  Dixie Chemical has a hurricane preparedness plan that includes shutting down manufacturing activities when hurricane threats are imminent.



Dixie remains committed to protecting our employees, the community and the environment through robust management systems and will always strive to improve our process and be good stewards for the industry.
